title: 111_hr2822
content:
The "Public Corruption Prosecution Improvements Act" extends the statute of limitations for serious public corruption offenses. The "Public Corruption Prosecution Improvements Act" amends Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a new section on corruption offenses, specifying certain violations that cannot be prosecuted. The "Public Corruption Prosecution Improvements Act" adds a new section to Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, specifying certain corruption offenses that cannot be prosecuted unless within 6 years of the offense. The amendments made by the "Public Corruption Prosecution Improvements Act" include changes to corruption offenses, theft or bribery concerning programs receiving federal financial assistance, addition of the District of Columbia to theft of public money offense, and additional RICO and money laundering predicates. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL RICO AND MONEYLAUNDERING PREDICATES. Amends Section 1961(1) of title 18, United States Code to include new predicates related to embezzlement, theft, and bribery concerning programs receiving Federal funds. Amends Section 1956(c)(7)(D) to remove specific references to public money and property. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL WIRETAP PREDICATES. Amends Section 2516(1)(c) of title 18, United States Code to include new predicates related to embezzlement or theft of public money, property, or records, and theft or bribery concerning programs receiving Federal funds. 

SEC. 7. CLARIFICATION OF CRIME OF ILLEGAL GRATUITIES. In Section 201(a) of title 18, United States Code, the definition of "rule or regulation" is expanded to include Federal regulations and rules of the House of Representatives or the Senate related to campaign contributions. In Section 201(c)(1), it is clarified that actions must be in accordance with the law or official duty, or by rule or regulation. In Section 201(a) of title 18, United States Code, the definition of "rule or regulation" is expanded to include Federal regulations and rules of the House of Representatives or the Senate related to campaign contributions. In Section 201(c)(1), actions must be in accordance with the law or official duty, or by rule or regulation. Subparagraphs (2) and (3) of Section 201 are amended to specify that gifts or benefits must not be given for or because of an official's position or any official act performed. SEC. 8 clarifies the definition of "official act" to include actions within official duty and decisions on pending matters. SEC. 9 authorizes additional personnel to investigate and prosecute public corruption offenses. Authorized $25,000,000 annually for 2010-2013 to DOJ, FBI, and Public Integrity Section to increase personnel for investigating and prosecuting public corruption offenses under various sections of Title 18, US Code.
